terms.definition: A blueprint that details how product documentation will appear to customers, including specific requirements, functionality, and design elements for the documentation itself.
Written materials that explain the use, creation, functionality, and architecture of products or technology to help users understand and operate them effectively.
Written specifications that define a product's appearance, capabilities, and how users will interact with it, providing detailed technical requirements.
Detailed profiles describing the target audience for a product, including demographics, needs, and problems the product will solve.
A description of how a user will interact with a specific feature or function of a product, explaining the benefit and practical application.
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted online and accessed via web browsers.
The final person who will actually use a product or system, as opposed to developers or administrators who build or maintain it.
The practice of creating clear, concise documentation that explains complex technical information to specific audiences.
Detailed specifications that define what a product must do, how it should perform, and what features it must include.
The structured approach to creating software applications, including planning, coding, testing, and deployment phases.
A document that provides instructions and guidance on how to use a product or system effectively.
The specific group of people for whom a product or documentation is designed and intended.
A feature that allows users to quickly find specific information within documentation by entering keywords or phrases.
Interactive documentation that can be updated in real-time and adapts to user needs or product changes.
Technical documents that have been converted from one language to another to serve international audiences.
